channel.title: American RadioWorks
channel.description: American Public Media's American RadioWorks creates documentaries, series projects, and investigative reports for the public radio system and the Internet.

item.title: Tracking and Vocational Ed
item.description: Jeannie Oakes, who has studied tracking for decades, says vocational ed and "tracking" are connected, and that sorting students by race and class is still a problem.
item.itunes:author: Andy Kruse
item.itunes:subtitle: Jeannie Oakes, who has studied tracking for decades, says vocational ed and "tracking" are connected, and that sorting students by race and class is still a problem.

item.title: Reinventing College for a New Kind of Student
item.description: Long-predicted demographic changes mean a new kind of student is figuring out where to go to college, and how to pay for it.
item.itunes:author: Andy Kruse
item.itunes:subtitle: Long-predicted demographic changes mean a new kind of student is figuring out where to go to college, and how to pay for it.

item.title: Is School Funding Fair?
item.description: A new report looks at why some schools have a lot of money to spend per pupil, while others don't, and what to do about it.
item.itunes:author: Andy Kruse
item.itunes:subtitle: A new report looks at why some schools have a lot of money to spend per pupil, while others don't, and what to do about it.

item.title: Who Needs College?
item.description: In May Stephen Smith was invited to be on a panel in Minneapolis that focused on the value of higher education. The panel answered questions such as: Who needs college?

item.title: Second-Chance Diploma
item.description: The General Educational Development test (GED) is a second chance for millions of school dropouts. Each year, more than 700,000 people take the GED test. People who pass it are supposed to posses a level of education and skills equivalent to those of a high school graduate. Most test-takers hope the GED will lead to a better job or more education. But critics say the GED encourages some students to drop out of school. And research shows the credential is of little value to most people who get one.

item.title: One Child at a Time
item.description: Learning with a personal tutor is one of the oldest and best ways to learn. Hiring a tutor for every student was never a realistic option. Now, new computer programs can customize education for each child. But adding computers to classrooms isn't likely to help unless teachers are willing to change their approach to teaching.

item.title: The Rise of Phoenix
item.description: For-profit colleges have deep roots in American history, but until recently they were a tiny part of the higher education landscape. Now they are big players. More than one in 10 college students attends a for-profit. The rapid rise of these career-oriented schools has provoked heated debate, opening up new conversations about the costs, quality and purpose of higher education. In this documentary, correspondent Emily Hanford examines the history and influence of the University of Phoenix, one of the nation's largest colleges, and explores how Phoenix and other for-profits are shaping the future of education.
item.itunes:author: Andy Kruse
